job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Lewiston, ME
pros: ICU was a great place to be a new nurse. There was great exposure to a wide variety of very sick patients with complex issues.
cons: It is extremely stressful to be a new grad in an ICU and this unit is no different. You have to be confident enough to let your peers and managers know when you don't know something and be able to clearly communicate what you need to learn.

pros: Support staff try their best but the load is high. The pharmacy is very helpful and knowledgeable.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Lewiston, ME
pros: The people that I worked with were some of the best people I have ever met. There are also plenty of people willing to help you grow and become a better nurse. This is a good place to learn.
cons: Administration doesn't care at all. They don't care about employees, and they don't care about patients. It is all numbers to them. In addition, they don't take any responsibility for their poor business decisions. They blame covid for the company being in the red, however they were in the red before covid. If you are thinking about working here, ask them to share their retention numbers, that will tell you everything you need to know.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Lewiston, ME
pros: They offer reasonable health insurance plan.  The starting wage is acceptable.  There are some good employee discounts offered.
cons: Training is minimal.  Policies as put forth by Human Resources are not consistently applied at satellite offices.  There are office politics involved in most offices.  If a person does not 'fit' the matrix it is a very uncomfortable environment to then work within.  There is no room to improve the fit once it is decided by management.  Rehiring is next to impossible if you did not 'fit' at one location.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Lewiston, ME
pros: Great co workers, good benefits, very close to work.  Safe and clean environment.  Medical staff very knowledgeable and helpful.
cons: Workload is stressful as we cannot keep ma’s and psr’s.  Rate of pay should relate to individual departments and not as an overall hospital wide rate.  Our office does a lot of testing to schedule and prior authorizations to get the testing done.

pros: Customer service is a priority for the IS department. There is satisfaction in helping the hospital staff.  Those that go over and above are encouraged and opportunites to problem solve are plentiful.
cons: With cut backs and hiring freez, employees that remain are overworked and sometimes doing the work of 2-4 positions. The culture is stressed and silo-ed.  Management rules with a strong arm and loud voices to intimidate workers.

pros: Staff are highly professional and collegial at Manager levels on down. Many are very long-tenured---20+ years. Most are passionate about their jobs and eagerly offer to assist others when needed.
cons: Never seems to be enough money for personnel, day to day tools and good salaries for skilled people. Workloads are heavy and increasing.

review_title: Not the worst place to work but not the best either.
pros: They have great benefits and discounts associated with your employment. They also have a good amount of personal time.
cons: It's difficult to propose anything new. It's not well received and there are a lot of office politics. Training is minimal. The pay is as minimal as possible and they do not give annual raises. There is no such thing as merit raises either.

pros: It's a nice community hospital that is well-integrated with smaller outlying regional hospitals and care centers and dedicated physician and nursing staff that provide needed medical services to the region.
cons: My department was losing money because of poor management, much of which was related to poor communication with providers and basic incompetence from being in over their heads; the Peter Principle at work.

review_title: I love working here. They get patients, mainly psych patients, that they can't handle and don't have the means to.
pros:
Pay is good
Hours are nice
No Overtime
Management is supportive
They help grow ideas that lead to improvements.
One of the best places I've worked at.
cons:
Have to adjust your schedule a lot
Lots of meetings
People don't understand their roles
No overtime, so you're basically salary with no ability to get extra money.

review_title: Smart, progressive management team makes this a thriving place to work
pros: New leadership has created a data-driven organization that has the potential and the know-how to really go places.
cons: It's hard to recruit and we have some jobs that need qualified candidates.  There may be a lingering reputation that causes this.

pros: I was treated with respect, excellent work-life balances in my departments, good coworkers, decent benefits.
cons: Hospital wide pay freeze which includes bonuses and raises.  Parking can be an issue at times.

pros: easy atmosphere, good people,great doctors, great cafeteria! I enjoy coming to work .the night shift compliments the day shift, system runs pretty smoothly.

pros: Some decent people work here, relatively decent equipment, on site gym, parking is never an issue

Poorly trained staff and a lack of communication and a lack of transparency. Dangerous place to work. Management is corrupt as well. Stay away

review_title: New management is ruining morale and turnover rates.
